text: When we look at the skills required to do your job, by 2030, it will change by 70%. So whether or not you're looking to change your job, your job is changing. In order to stay competitive, you actually have to go back to some first principles, go back to the drawing board and reimagine what it means to be building.
speaker: Tomer Cohen
context: Lenny asks Tomer why he decided to completely rethink how product development works at LinkedIn and why other leaders need to pay attention to this transformation. Tomer explains that LinkedIn has unique visibility into the changing nature of work, and their data shows that 70% of the skills required for any given job will change by 2030. This rapid pace of change means companies must fundamentally reimagine their approach to building products to stay competitive.
vocabulary_highlights: go back to some first principles
go back to the drawing board
reimagine what it means to be building
text_ko: 여러분의 일을 해내는 데 필요한 스킬은 2030년까지 약 70%가 바뀔 거예요. 그래서 이직을 고려하든 안 하든, 지금 하고 있는 일이 변하고 있다는 뜻이에요. 경쟁력을 유지하려면 기본 원리(first principles)로 돌아가 백지에서 다시 시작하듯 도면을 다시 그려보고, ‘무엇을 만드는 것(building)’이 무엇인지 다시 상상해봐야 해요.
text_zh: 你看啊，到2030年的时候，你现在这份工作需要的技能会有70%都变掉。所以不管你想不想换工作，反正工作本身已经在变了。想要保持竞争力，你得回到最基本的原理上，重新来过，重新思考什么叫做"建设"。
text_es: Cuando miramos las habilidades que vas a necesitar para tu trabajo, para el 2030 van a cambiar en un 70%. O sea que quieras cambiar de trabajo o no, tu trabajo se está transformando. Para mantenerte competitivo, en realidad tienes que volver a lo básico, empezar desde cero y replantearte completamente lo que significa construir.

text: We call it the full stack builder model. The goal itself is to empower great builders to take their idea and to take it to market, regardless of their role and the stack and which team they're on. It's really fluid interaction between human and machine.
speaker: Tomer Cohen
context: Lenny asks Tomer to explain the name and concept of the new program LinkedIn has developed. The full stack builder model is LinkedIn's radical approach to product development that enables individual contributors to take products from idea to launch regardless of their traditional function. Unlike traditional teams where product managers, designers, and engineers work in sequence, this model creates a seamless collaboration between humans and AI tools.
text_ko: 우리는 그걸 풀스택 빌더 모델(full stack builder model)이라고 불러요. 목표는 훌륭한 빌더들이 자신의 아이디어를 어떤 역할을 맡고 있든, 어떤 스택(stack)을 쓰고 있든, 어떤 팀에 속해 있든 상관없이 아이디어를 실현해 시장에 내놓을 수 있도록 역량을 실어 주는 거예요. 사람과 기계가 유연하게 상호작용하는 방식이에요.
text_zh: 我们叫它全栈构建者模式(full stack builder model)。目标就是让那些厉害的构建者能够把自己的想法推向市场，不管他们在哪个岗位、用什么技术栈(stack)、在哪个团队。这其实就是人和机器之间很流畅的互动。
text_es: Lo llamamos el modelo de constructor integral (full stack builder). El objetivo en sí es empoderar a los grandes constructores para que tomen su idea y la lleven al mercado, sin importar cuál sea su rol, en qué parte del stack estén o en qué equipo trabajen. Es realmente una interacción fluida entre el humano y la máquina.

text: Change management here is going to be a critical part, but it's not enough to give them the tools. You have to build the incentives programs, the motivation, the examples to how you do it. I see a lot of companies roll out their agents and just expecting companies to adopt. It doesn't work this way.
speaker: Tomer Cohen
context: Lenny observes that top performers are finding the most success with AI tools and asks about adoption challenges. Tomer explains that simply providing AI tools to employees isn't sufficient for organizational transformation. He emphasizes that successful adoption requires comprehensive change management including performance incentives, motivational programs, and concrete examples of success. He notes that many companies fail by just deploying AI agents without supporting the cultural shift needed for adoption.
text_ko: 여기서 변화 관리(change management)는 핵심인데, 도구만 주는 것으로는 부족해요. 인센티브 프로그램(incentive programs)과 동기 부여, 어떻게 하는지 보여주는 사례들을 만들어야 해요. 많은 회사들이 에이전트(agents)를 배포해 놓고 알아서 채택되길 기대하는데, 그렇게 되지 않아요.
text_zh: 变革管理(change management)在这里会是关键一环，但光给他们工具还不够。你得建立激励机制、调动积极性，还要给出具体的操作示例。我看到很多公司就是把代理工具(agents)一推出去，就指望企业会自动采用。这样搞肯定不行的。
text_es: La gestión del cambio va a ser clave aquí, pero no basta con darles las herramientas. Tienes que crear programas de incentivos, la motivación, ejemplos de cómo hacerlo. Veo muchas empresas que lanzan sus agentes y simplemente esperan que las compañías los adopten. Así no funciona la cosa.

text: Top talent has this tendency of continuously trying to get better at their craft. The key trait that I'm emphasizing for builders is where I want them to spend their time is where I think great builders should shine in.
speaker: Tomer Cohen
context: Lenny questions whether AI makes average people better or makes great people even better. Tomer confirms that LinkedIn's top performers are the most successful with their new AI-powered tools, explaining that high performers naturally seek to improve their craft and stay at the cutting edge. He then transitions to describing the specific traits he wants builders to focus on - vision, empathy, communication, creativity, and judgment - rather than automatable tasks.
text_ko: 최고 인재들은 자신의 실력을 계속해서 더 나아지게 하려는 경향이 있어요. 제가 빌더들(builders)에게 특히 강조하는 핵심은 그들이 시간을 어디에 쓰느냐인데, 바로 그 지점에서 훌륭한 빌더들이 빛나야 한다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 顶尖人才都有一个特点，就是会不断地想要在自己的专业领域做得更好。我特别看重做产品的人(builders)的一个品质，就是我希望他们把时间花在真正能让优秀产品人发光发热的地方。
text_es: El talento de primera tiene esa tendencia de siempre estar tratando de mejorar en lo suyo. La característica clave que les recalco a los que construyen es en qué quiero que inviertan su tiempo, ahí es donde creo que los grandes constructores realmente deben brillar.

text: We ended up building our own trust agent at LinkedIn. So when you build a spec, you build an idea, you walk through the trust agent and it'll basically tell you what are your vulnerabilities, what harm vectors potentially you're introducing or will be introduced as a result of that.
speaker: Tomer Cohen
context: Lenny asks about the specific AI agents LinkedIn has built to automate parts of product development. Tomer explains that LinkedIn couldn't use off-the-shelf AI tools and had to build custom agents tailored to their specific needs. The trust agent is one example - it analyzes product specifications and identifies potential security vulnerabilities and harm vectors that could affect users. This agent was built by LinkedIn's head of trust and incorporates all their unique trust considerations.
text_ko: 결국 LinkedIn에서 저희만의 트러스트 에이전트(trust agent)를 만들게 되었어요. 그래서 스펙(spec)을 만들거나 아이디어를 구체화할 때 그 에이전트로 쭉 검토해 보면, 어떤 취약점이 있는지와 그로 인해 어떤 피해 벡터(harm vectors)가 생기거나 유발될 수 있는지를 알려줘요.
text_zh: 我们最后在LinkedIn自己搭建了一个信任代理(trust agent)。所以当你在做规划、构思想法的时候，你把这些过一遍信任代理，它基本上就能告诉你有哪些漏洞，可能会带来什么样的风险点，或者说因为这个决定可能会产生什么隐患。
text_es: Terminamos creando nuestro propio agente de confianza en LinkedIn. Entonces, cuando armas una especificación, cuando desarrollas una idea, la pasas por el agente de confianza y básicamente te dice cuáles son tus vulnerabilidades, qué vectores de daño (harm vectors) potencialmente estás introduciendo o que se van a introducir como resultado de eso.

text: Whether you're in an organization, you're waiting for your leader to roll this out or you're a leader trying to roll this out, I would not wait. If you're looking for a formal reorg or declaration to start building differently, you're waiting too long.
speaker: Tomer Cohen
context: In his final advice, Lenny asks what leaders should know about implementing similar AI-powered product development changes. Tomer emphasizes urgency and personal agency rather than waiting for organizational permission. He argues that individuals should start experimenting with AI tools and adopting a full-stack builder mindset immediately, regardless of whether their company has formally announced such programs. He believes waiting for official reorganizations or declarations will put people behind in the rapidly changing landscape.
text_ko: 조직 안에서 리더가 이걸 도입(roll out)해 주길 기다리든, 리더로서 직접 도입하려 하든, 저는 기다리지 말라고 권해요. 형식적인 재편(reorg)이나 선언을 기다려서 다르게 만들어 가기 시작하려 한다면, 이미 너무 늦었어요.
text_zh: 不管你是在公司里等着领导推这个事儿，还是你就是那个要推的领导，我觉得都别等了。如果你还在等什么正式的重组或者官方声明才开始换个思路做事，那就等太久了。
text_es: Ya sea que estés en una organización esperando a que tu jefe implemente esto, o seas tú el líder tratando de implementarlo, yo no esperaría. Si estás esperando una reestructuración formal o una declaración oficial para empezar a construir de manera diferente, te estás tardando demasiado.
